I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  (i)  a  proposed 
loan, (ii) proposed administration of a loan to be provided by the ADB Clean Technology Fund 
(ADB CTF), and (iii) proposed administration of a grant to be provided by the ADB CTF, to the 
Republic  of  the  Philippines  for  the  Market  Transformation  through  Introduction  of  Energy-
Efficient Electric Vehicles Project.1 
 
The  proposed  project  will  replace  100,000  gasoline  tricycles  (motorcycles  with  a 
2. 
passenger  sidecar)  with  three wheel  plug-in  electric  vehicles  running  on an  electric motor  and 
rechargeable battery (e-trikes). The project will initiate a transformation of the tricycle subsector 
by  (i)  improving  the  livelihoods  of  tricycle  drivers  through  higher  incomes  and  a  better  work 
environment; (ii) generating global  environmental  benefits  and reducing the  carbon footprint of 
the  tricycle  industry  through  the  introduction  of  low-carbon,  e-trike  technology;  and  (iii) 
leveraging private sector participation in the e-trike market. The Government of the Philippines 
plans  to  introduce  clean  and  efficient  energy  technology,  provide  affordable  financing 
modalities,  generate  demand,  develop  technical  capacity,  create  support  infrastructure,  and 
allocate new technology risk to the suppliers. The government will target selected cities in Metro 
Manila and other urban centers where tricycles are widely used. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Rationale 

In 2011, the Philippines spent about $12.8 billion (29% more than in 2010) on imported 
3. 
petroleum  products;  70%  of the  imports  went to the  transport  sector.2 This  heavy  dependence 
on imported fuels renders the country vulnerable to energy supply disruptions and global price 
fluctuations. The  cost  of fuel  imports  is  expected to  rise further  as  the  population continues  to 
grow  rapidly  and  urbanization  increases.  With  motorization  growing  at  about  6%  per  year, 
emissions  from  road  transport  are  estimated  to  rise  from  24  million  tons  of  carbon  dioxide 
equivalent (tCO2e) in 2007 to 37 million tCO2e by 2015 and 87 million tCO2e by 2030. This will 
further  deteriorate  the  country’s  air-quality  and  energy  security,  and  increase  the  Philippines’ 
carbon footprint. The National Framework Strategy on Climate  Change, 2010–20223 considers 
a low-carbon path  in the  transport  sector  a  strategic  priority.  It  argues for  cleaner,  indigenous, 
and  optimized  energy  and  transport  sectors  to  enable  the  Philippines  to  address  its  energy 
security while reducing pollution. 
 
4. 
Transport  is  central  to  connecting  people  and  economic  centers  both  nationally  and 
locally.  In  2010,  according  to  the  Philippines’  Department  of  Energy  (DOE),  using  Land 
Transport  Office’s  vehicles  statistics,  92%  of  the  transport  sector’s  fuel  consumption  was  by 
road  transport.  Although  public  vehicles  represent  only  about  15%  of  road  transport,  they  are 
major fuel users and cause most of the transport pollution—tricycles account for 67%, followed 
by jeepneys4 (23%), cars (4%) and buses (6%). The 3.5 million tricycles currently operating are 
major contributors of greenhouse gas emissions and inefficient users of imported fuel. Although 
local government units (LGUs) regulate the number of tricycles, this will rise as motorcycle sales

 increase.  About  1  million  motorcycles  are  expected  to  be  sold  domestically  in  2012,  nearly  a 
third more than the 760,000 units sold in 2010. 
 
5. 
The International Energy Agency considers electric vehicles as one of the best options 
for the transport sector, especially in urban areas.5 Recent studies by the Clean Air Initiatives for 
Asian  Cities  estimate  that  switching  to  e-trikes  will  reduce  the  greenhouse  gas  impact  of 
tricycles  by  54%.6 International  studies  also  point  to  similar  savings.7 Tricycles  are  a  popular 
mode  of  local  transport  in  the  Philippines  and  are  run  entirely  by  the  private  sector.  In  many 
cases, they provide a vital link as a local feeder service to the larger-public transport network. 
Although  the  government  has  banned  the  importation  of  two-stroke  motorcycles8 the  existing 
two-stroke engines are easy to fix and continue to be used in tricycles. Isolated initiatives since 
2009  to  develop  an  e-vehicle  industry—e-trikes,  e-jeepneys,  and  e-buses—mostly  used  lead-
acid  or  substandard  lithium-ion  batteries  because  of  cost  considerations  and  limited  brand 
availability.  
 
6. 
In  April  2011,  ADB  and  DOE  piloted,  20  locally  made  e-trikes  powered  by  imported 
lithium-ion  batteries  in  Mandaluyong, 9 a  city  in  Metro  Manila.  Collectively,  the  e-trikes  have 
traveled more than 600,000 kilometers (km) in 20 months, and the pilot project have collected a 
net  total  of  $16,000  as  drivers’  daily  ―lease‖  payments.  Surveys  from  the  pilot-testing  showed 
that  e-trike  operators  carried  more  passengers,  implying  higher  turnover  and  daily  income.  By 
switching  fuels,  the  e-trike  operators  doubled  their  average  daily  net  income  to  $17.  This 
additional income will help with loan repayments for a new e-trike in the future. Driver feedback 
on the handling and operating of an e-trike has been used in designing an improved model for 
the proposed scale up. 
 
7. 
Although the drivers and passengers are satisfied with the performance of the pilot units, 
keeping  all  20  operating  has  been  a  challenge.10 Problems  include  (i)  a  lack  of  reliable  spare 
parts,  (ii)  inadequate  technical  skills  to  repair  and  maintain  the  motors  and  batteries,  and  (iii) 
concerns over the battery life beyond the second year as the pilot project was unable to secure 
batteries  from  reputable  brands.  The  lessons  from  the  pilot  project  confirmed  the  need  for 
significant  scaling  up  to  ensure  the  sustainability  of  the  e-vehicle  initiative  and  to  attract 
reputable e-vehicle and battery technology holders to the Philippines. To scale-up the program, 
e-trike manufacturing and maintenance will have to be localized to ensure that the need for after 
sales services, repairs, spare parts, and battery warranties are met. Development of a local e-
trike industry will help minimize technology risk, broaden the adoption of e-vehicles, and create 
jobs.  The  government  has  started  scaling  up  of  the  pilot  project 11  to  establish  a  viable, 
sustainable,  local  e-vehicle  industry  with  the  participation  of  several  local  and  international  e-
trike  manufacturers.  In  response  to  this  initiative,  several  reputable  global  battery  and  car 
manufacturers have expressed interest in investing in the country.

2 

 

 With  about  3.5  million  tricycles  currently  operating  and  a  growing  number  of  new 
8. 
tricycles being registered, a transformation of the industry to clean technology e-trikes will take 
time.  The  e-trikes  are  expected  to  be  introduced  largely  through  substitution  for  gasoline- 
powered units (i.e. non-incremental). This is expected to be followed by generated demand from 
new  entrants  to  the  e-trike  market  as  the  affordable  clean  technology  becomes  more  widely 
available. A survey of local governments found an immediate demand for more than 130,000 e-
trikes.  Based  on this  interest, the government  plans  to  initially  scale-up  the  project to  100,000 
units  in  a  phased  manner,  in  order  to  create  an  environment  conducive  to  the  manufacture, 
distribution  and  after-sale  support  of  the  e-trikes.  As  the  private  sector  gains  a foothold  in  the 
supply and maintenance market for e-trikes, the government’s involvement will shrink.   
 
9. 
The introduction of e-trikes with lithium-ion battery technology is also expected to pave 
the way for higher safety standards and improved environmental compliance. The proposed e-
vehicle  project  complements  the  government’s  plans  to  support  e-vehicle  businesses. 12 To 
pursue  this  transformation,  the  government  has  secured  a  $5  million  grant  and  $100  million 
concessional  loan  from  the  CTF.  The  project  is  consistent  with  DOE’s  Fueling  Sustainable 
Transport Program,13 and with ADB’s Energy Policy 2009 (promotes projects to support energy 
security  needs  and  transition  to  a  low-carbon  economy)  and  sustainable  transport  initiative14 
(focuses  on  transport  systems that  are  accessible,  safe,  affordable,  and environment-friendly). 
The promotion of energy-efficient transportation is part of the ADB’s current country partnership 
strategy15 for  Philippines,  and  the  program  is  in  the  country  operations  business  plan,  2012–
2014.16  
 
10. 
The market for new e-trike technology to replace existing tricycles and meet generated 
demand is potentially large given the rapid growth of the industry. To initiate the government’s 
plan to transform the industry through e-trike technology, the project must capture economies of 
scale by ensuring that the supply of e-trike technology and services is cost effective and meets 
aggregate  as  well  as  diverse  local  demand  and  conditions.  The  design  of  the  e-trike  has 
evolved through the pilot phase to cater to a range of conditions in the Philippines. The selected 
e-trike design uses a standard, high-quality lithium-ion battery and higher safety standard, which 
is  expected  to  result  in  cost-effective  market  entry  for  national  and  international  investors, 
including  reputable  e-vehicle  producers  and  components  manufacturers.  It  will  also  facilitate 
cost-effective  after  sales  service.  Successfully  establishing  the  industry  in  the  Philippines  will 
also create jobs beyond the e-trike operators and has the potential for growth into other South 
and Southeast Asian markets. 
 
B. 

Impact and Outcome 

11. 
The  impact  of  the  project  will  be  sustainable  energy  use  by  the  transport  sector.  The 
outcome  will  be  the  transformation  of  public  transportation  through  large-scale  adoption  of 
locally made energy-efficient electric vehicles, in particular e-trikes.

C. 

Outputs  

The project has five outputs. 

Output  4:  Materials  recovery.  A  mechanism  will  be  established  for  collecting  and 

Output 2: Battery supply chain. The project will initiate creation of a lithium-ion battery 

12. 
 
Output  1:  E-trike  units.  The  project  will  deliver  100,000  complete  e-trike  units  to 
13. 
selected cities or municipalities to replace gasoline tricycles, with a comprehensive warranty on 
batteries and mechanical parts to ensure technical reliability and after-sales service.  
 
14. 
supply chain by procuring at least 300 MWh of lithium ion batteries for the 100,000 e-trikes.  
  
 
15. 
Output  3:  Solar  and  grid-connected  charging  stations.  The  project  will  (i)  pilot  five 
off-grid solar charging stations, 200 kilo Watts each, sufficient to meet the demand of 1,000 e-
trikes; and (ii) establish grid-connected charging stations. Some pilot solar charging stations will 
be  in  island  locations  outside  the  main  grid  that  are  easily  accessible  and  plan  to  adopt  large 
number of e-trikes.  
 
16. 
disposing existing passenger sidecars of tricycles and spent lithium-ion batteries.   
 
Output  5:  Communication,  social  mobilization,  and  technology  transfer.  All 
17. 
stakeholders  will  be  educated  about  the  project’s  benefits,  technical  parameters,  costs,  and 
market potential of e-trikes. This will include training the drivers on the use and maintenance of 
e-trikes and technical training for other stakeholders to develop human resources to support the 
development of the local industry.   
 
D. 
 
The project is estimated to cost $504 million (Table 1). The government has requested a 
18. 
loan of $300 million from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to help finance the project. The loan 
will  have  a  20-year  term,  including  a  grace  period  of  5  years,  an  interest  rate  determined  in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending  facility,  and  a 
commitment  charge of  0.15%  per  annum,  and  such  other  terms  and conditions  as set forth in 
the draft loan and project agreements. The government has provided ADB with (i) the reasons 
for its decision to borrow under ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility based on these terms and 
conditions and (ii) an undertaking that these choices were its own independent decision and not 
made  based  on  any  communication  or  advice  from  ADB.  Based  on  such  loan  terms  and 
repayment method, the average loan maturity is 12.75 years and there is no maturity premium 
payable to ADB. 
 
The CTF will cofinance the project with a grant of $5 million and a loan of $100 million, 
19. 
with  a  40-year  term,  including  a  grace  period  of  10  years,  a  management  fee  of  0.18%  per 
annum  on  the  undisbursed  balance  of  the  loan,  and  an  interest  charge  of  0.25%.  ADB  will 
administer  the  CTF  funds.  ADB  and  CTF  loans  will  finance  the  financial  charges  during 
construction.  The  government  will  finance  the  remaining  $99  million,  including  taxes  and 
contingency amounts for the e-trikes.

E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

20. 
The project will be implemented over 60 months from January 2013 to December 2017. 
It will have two phases: an industry development phase (24–30 months) when the initial 20,000 
e-trikes  will  be  procured  and  distributed,  and  (ii)  a  scale-up  phase  (30−36  months)  when  the 
remaining  80,000  units  will  be  procured  and  distributed.  ADB  and  DOE  will  conduct  a 
comprehensive midterm assessment of the project, which will include options for expanding into 
other public e-vehicles, before implementing phase 2.  

5 

 

 6 

 

 

 

DOE will be the executing agency responsible for procurement, overall implementation,  
21. 
and technical  supervision  of the  project.  DOE  will  manage the  supply  and service contracts  of 
the  suppliers.  DOE  has  established  E-Trike  Group,  which  will  become  the  e-trike  project 
management  unit,  and  will  include  DOE  staff,  supported  by  implementation  consultants  with 
technical expertise. It will directly manage and supervise implementation of the project.  
 
22. 
Prior to  the  distribution of  e-trikes,  a government financial  institution (GFI)  with  existing 
lending  operations  in  the  municipalities,  such  as  the  Land  Bank  of  the  Philippines  (LBP),  will 
establish a loan facility with the LGU to cover the cost of the e-trikes. The government will enter 
into  a  separate  agreement  with  the  GFI  on  the  financial  terms  of  the  loans  from  GFI  to  each 
selected  LGU.  The  LGU  will  take  the  driver’s  credit  risk  as  they  are  in  a  better  position  to 
assume  such  risk.  The  choice  of  the  GFI  may  vary  depending  on  the  municipality  and  GFI’s 
interest,  availability  of  retail  branch  in  local  area,  etc.  The  e-trikes  will  be  distributed  in  three 
steps:  (i)  ADB  will  pay  the  competitively  selected  suppliers  directly  upon  DOE’s  request 
(withdrawal  application),  (ii)  the  supplier  will  deliver  the  e-trike  to  the  LGU  concerned  in 
accordance with an agreed upon schedule, and (iii) the LGU’s e-trike office will distribute the e-
trikes to drivers pre-selected based on a transparent lottery with priority to two stroke tricycles.  
  
23. 
The collected funds from the drivers and payment back to government will also involve 
three steps: (i) the drivers will pay a daily amount as part of the ―lease to own‖ scheme either to 
the e-trike office, or to a bank account or to a third party responsible for collection (this activity 
will  be  ―ring-fenced‖  from  the  LGU);  (ii)  the  collection  from  the  drivers  will  be  used  to  pay  the 
GFI; and (iii) the GFI will pay DOF’s Bureau of Treasury. The implementation arrangements are

 A. 

Technical  

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

ADB initially pilot tested two battery options: the lithium-ion batteries (38 kilograms) were 
24. 
72% lighter than the lead-acid ones (140 kilograms). The lithium-ion battery was subsequently 
piloted  in  20  e-trikes  with  different  battery  sizes  and  charging  options.  Despite  problems  with 
service and technical support, the pilot units have performed well overall. Collectively they have 
driven more than 600,000 km on both city and hilly terrain.18 The pilot concluded that (i) lithium-
ion  batteries  are  an  environmentally  sustainable  battery  choice;  (ii)  technically  appropriate  e-
trike designs are capable of meeting the variable range, speed, and terrain considerations in the 
Philippines;  and (iii) the fuel  savings  are  significant  and  sufficient  to support  a  lease-to-own  e-
trike  scheme  for  the  drivers.  However,  because  of  the  sophisticated  battery  and  charging 
technologies,  the  drivers  and  LGUs  will  be  unable  to  manage  the  risk  of  a  faulty  battery.  To 
address this technical risk, the project will ensure that the batteries have a 3-year warranty and 
payments to the supplier are staggered to match the warranty period.  
 
B. 

Sustainability 

25. 
The lack of local technical support and spare parts has been a recurring reason for failed 
e-vehicle  initiatives.  Recognizing  that  drivers  do  not  earn  any  income  when  their  tricycles  are 
not  operational,  the  project  will  ensure  that  they  have  access  to  a  standby  e-trike  or  are 
compensated  by  the  supplier  for  any  losses  within  the  warranty  period.  To  address  the  pilot 
project’s  lessons  regarding  the  need  for  after-sales  services,  arrangements  will  be  made  for 
easy access to repair services, and technical components will be covered by a comprehensive 
warranty.  Suppliers  will  be  required  to  establish  local  support  centers  to  honor  warranty 
obligations  efficiently.  Private  sector  suppliers  are  expected  to  provide  the  after-sales  service, 
spare parts, and technical skills for maintenance after the warranty period as sufficient market 
demand will have been created. To promote sustainability, $1 million from the CTF grant will be 
used for fine-tuning technology options, technology transfer, local industry support, and capacity 
building.  Each  driver  will  also  be  required  to  undergo  a  comprehensive  training  program 
covering  (i)  general  introduction  to  e-vehicles  and  their  components,  (ii)  troubleshooting,  (iii) 
maintenance,  (iv)  charging  options,  (v)  safety,  (vi)  energy-efficient  driving  instructions,  (vii)  the 
warranty,  and  (viii)  a  driver’s  responsibility.  Manuals  with  clear  illustrations  in  the  local  dialect 
will also be distributed.  
 
C. 
 
26. 
A detailed financial analysis was carried out in real terms using 2012 prices to examine 
the  aggregate  costs  and  incremental  benefits measured by the  revenue from  drivers  or  users. 
Based  on  field  data  from  the  pilot,  a  typical  tricycle  driver  who  uses  about  $6.50  worth  of 
gasoline (5.5 liters) to drive 80 km per day can save about $5 per day by switching to an e-trike, 
which  consumes  6  kilowatt-hour  of  power  costing  $1.50  per  day. The  financial  internal  rate  of 
return  (FIRR)  exceeds  47%  from  the  driver’s  perspective. The  FIRR  remained  robust  under 
sensitivity  testing  and  in  the most  severe  case  of  a  daily  lease payment increase by  10%, the 
FIRR declined to 16.5%. The government expects the cost of the e-trike office in an LGU will be 
equivalent  of  2%-3%  of  the  drivers’  rental  payment  each  month;  there  will  be  no  cost 
implications  for  the  LGU’s  current  budget.  As  suppliers  become  established  and  operator 
demand grows, the initial support role and supervision costs to the government will decline.

D. 

Economic  

27. 
A  policy  objective  of  the  project  is  to  generate  demand  for  clean  and  efficient  e-trike 
technology,  although,  the  new  units  will  initially  substitute  for  old  gasoline-powered  tricycles. 
The  project’s  economic  analysis  is  based  on  the  non-incremental  cost  and  benefit  streams,  
comparing  the  ―with  project‖  and  ―without  project‖  scenarios.  Benefits  are  derived  mainly  from 
the  fuel  savings  or  avoided  costs  from  the  importation  of  fuel.  The  economic  internal  rate  of 
return  (EIRR)  is  23.7%, which  exceeds  the  economic  hurdle  of  12%.19 This  indicates  that  the 
project is economically viable. Sensitivity analysis shows the EIRR drops to 17.5% if the price of 
imported oil falls by 20%. The main project beneficiaries will be e-trike drivers. Assuming about 
five people depend on each driver’s income, about 500,000 people will directly benefit from the 
project’s  output.  The  fabrication  of  e-trikes  and  assembly  will  be  domestic.  The  project  could 
create about 10,000 jobs by 2015 with employment increasing as the e-trike industry grows. E-
trike drivers, passengers and the population at large will benefit from reduced emissions from e-
trikes.    
 
E. 

Governance 

28. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government and DOE. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are  described  in  the  PAM.  To  ensure  transparency  and  good  governance,  DOE  will  publicly 
disclose  on  its  website  information  on  how  loan  proceeds  are  being  used.  ADB  will  organize 
special  training  for  GFIs,  DOE,  and  project  management  unit  staff,  and  participating  LGUs 
covering  all  aspects  of  project  implementation  and  ADB  procedures,  including  procedures  for 
implementation,  procurement,  use  of  consultants,  disbursement,  reporting,  monitoring,  and 
prevention of fraud and corruption. 
 
F. 

Poverty, Social, and Gender 

29. 
An  e-trike  will  increase  the  daily  take-home  pay  of  its  driver,  with  fuel  savings  alone 
(para  26)  generating  about  of  $1,800  per  year  for  drivers  and  their  families.  This  is  also 
expected  to  facilitate  higher  trike  ownership  (only  8%  of  drivers  in  Davao  were  owners 
compared  with  40%  in  Boracay).  The  fuel  cost  savings  of  $5  per  day  will  greatly  benefit  the 
driver community and are the basis for the lease-to-own scheme. The project will not displace, 
or negatively affect the livelihoods of, tricycle drivers or families. Other developmental benefits 
will  include  better  health  for  drivers,  passengers  and  urban  residents  through  lower  trike 
emissions; new skills development; job creation; and the establishment of a vehicle and spare 
parts supply industry. The additional net income of e-vehicle drivers and owners are expected to 
be largely used in the participating communities. 
 
The  pilot  e-trike  design  has  accounted  for  women’s  needs.  Female  passengers  were 
30. 
consulted  on  the  design  and  safety  aspects  of  proposed  e-trike  models,  especially  for  Metro 
Manila.  As  this  is  a  replacement  program,  the  scope  for  female  drivers  will  be  limited.  ADB's 
target is for at least 30% of charging station jobs to be filled by women (only for daytime shifts) 
and  necessary  training  will  be  included.  Female  workers  will  also  be  trained  to  inspect  the  e-
trikes  for  basic  safety  issues  (roadworthiness,  for  example)  and  collect  e-trike  operation  data. 
The health and safety benefits of the new design will be significant for the population, especially 
children.

 G. 

Safeguards 

Special Features 

31. 
 The  project  is  category  C  for  environment,  involuntary  resettlement  and  indigenous 
people. It will bring positive environmental and socioeconomic benefits because the e-trikes will 
not generate any air or noise pollution, and will replace gasoline powered tricycles that use lead-
acid batteries. A framework on material recovery and proper handling of old tricycles and used 
batteries  has  been  developed.20 In  compliance  with  government’s  environmental  regulations 
and ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), this framework describes the disposal options, 
which  will  be  evaluated  further  during  implementation,  for  old  tricycles  and  their  lead-acid 
batteries as well as used lithium-ion batteries from the e-trikes. It also identifies the stakeholders 
and  institutions  involved  and  their  responsibilities.  This  framework  will  be  improved  following 
further consultations.21  
 
H. 
 
32. 
The project aims to create a competitive local e-vehicle industry using the latest battery 
and charging options, including solar charging. The project uses financing from the CTF22 as an 
integral  part  of  the  project  design  for  market  transformation.  The  envisaged  market  shift  from 
gasoline-power tricycles to  e-trikes  powered by cleaner,  more  efficient  lithium-ion  batteries  will 
(i)  increase  access  to  and  the  commercialization  of  technology,  (ii)  establish  local  service 
delivery and after sales support arrangements, (iii) introduce publicly available charging stations 
for e-vehicles, and (iv) develop the local manufacturing of e-trikes. The development impacts of 
the project are the initiation of a public sector-driven transformation of the tricycle industry into a 
low-carbon industry that improves the welfare of e-trike operators.    
 
33.

and  operational  e-trike  is  likely  to  be  about  3.8  ton  per  year  of  carbon  dioxide  equivalent
